sections.doc_: For the purpose of this sample, we're creating some helper CSS classes that use the CSS rules defined by `amp-dynamic-css-classes`.  These allow us to more succinctly refer to the conditions in our code below.
sections.code:
<style amp-custom>
  :root {
    --space-2: 1rem;   /* 16px */
  }
  body:not(.amp-referrer-pinterest-com) .if-pinterest,
  body:not(.amp-referrer-ampbyexample-com) .if-ampbyexample,
  body:not(.amp-referrer-google-com) .if-google,
  body:not(.amp-referrer-twitter-com) .if-twitter,
  body:not(.amp-referrer-linkedin-com) .if-linkedin,
  body:not(.amp-referrer-localhost) .if-localhost {
    display: none;
  }
  body:not(.amp-viewer) .if-viewer,
  body.amp-viewer .if-not-viewer {
    display: none;
  }
  .dynamic-css {
    padding: var(--space-2);
  }
</style>
sections.normalizedDoc_: For the purpose of this sample, we're creating some helper CSS classes that use the CSS rules defined by `amp-dynamic-css-classes`.  These allow us to more succinctly refer to the conditions in our code below.

sections.doc_: Using these referrer classes can allow you to conditionally include elements. You do not need to include a call to the `amp-dynamic-css-classes` component to initialize the classes on the body element.

sections.doc_: The 'viewer' classes enable you to style the page based on whether it's embedded inside an AMP viewer. Try it out on the [Google AMP Viewer](https://google.com/amp/ampbyexample.com/components/amp-dynamic-css-classes/). Note this works only on a mobile device or in your browser's mobile emulation mode.
